item.title: Monopoly GO: Today's Event Schedule & Best Strategy (December 16, 2024)
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Monopoly GO Events Schedule for December 16, 2024
  • Best Monopoly GO Strategy For December 16, 2024

As the Haunted Mansion minigame draws to a close in Monopoly GO , it is your final chance to claim the limited-edition Grumpy Ghost Token and Ghost Goo Shield. To maximize your success, don’t forget to leverage the power cards in your deck. If you’ve already completed all six levels in the Haunted Mansion, now is the time to focus on completing your missing sticker sets in the Jingle Joy album. To help you out, this guide outlines Monopoly GO ’s schedule for December 16, 2024, and the best strategy to get the most out of all the events today.

Monopoly GO Events Schedule for December 16, 2024

Monopoly GO has another exciting lineup of events for December 16, 2024. Check out the sections below for a complete list of today’s events.

All Monopoly GO events listed here are based on recent trends and are subject to change by Scopely at any time.

Best Monopoly GO Strategy For December 16, 2024

To collect more Compass tokens for the Haunted Mansion minigame, catching the early High Roller should be your top priority in Monopoly GO today . Moreover, the start of the week means the Quick Wins bar will reset , giving you a fresh chance to earn Compass tokens and get closer to kicking the ghosts out of Mr. M’s mansion.

It’s also a good idea to build during the Board Rush to set your boards up for the late night Wheel Boost. This way, you can earn a bunch of extra sticker packs and dice rolls in Monopoly GO .

item.title: No Man's Sky: How to Get Cadmium
item.description:
Some of the resources in No Man's Sky are only found in the distant systems that you can't go to right away. Cadmium is one of the resources you'll need early on in the game, and you may be left slightly confused about how to get it.

Here's a complete guide to everything you need to know about Cadmium in No Man's Sky , including how to get it and what it's used for.

How to Get Cadmium in No Man's Sky

Cadmium only appears in red star systems that look like red dots on the Galaxy Map. You must install a Cadmium Drive on your starship to travel to one of these systems. It's an upgrade to the hyperdrive that you can pick up on the Anomaly at the starship upgrade NPC. Cadmium Drive requires 250 Chromatic Metal and 3 Wiring Looms to build.

Red star systems don't have space stations. This means you have to fly in and out using a hyperdrive unless you decide to build a base or use your freighter with the Amplified Warp Shielding upgrade . Any vendors and services that you usually find on space stations are also, naturally, unavailable.

Equipped with the Cadmium Drive, open the Galaxy Map and warp to the nearest red system. Once there, use the ship's scanner on the planets to view their resources , as not every planet in the system will have Cadmium.

Land on the planet, find the deposit and use the Terrain Manipulator to mine Cadmium. Alternatively, you can install an Autonomous Mining Unit over the Cadmium deposit. In that case, you should also consider setting up a base on the planet with the teleporter for quick and easy access to Cadmium.​​​​​​​

What is Cadmium used for in No Man's Sky?

Cadmium has only a few uses in No Man's Sky . The main one is to craft the Emeril Drive upgrade for the starship's hyperdrive and the Amplified Warp Shielding upgrade for the freighter's hyperdrive. These upgrades allow you to warp into the green star systems where you can find Emeril.

Another use for Cadmium is to craft an AtlasPass v2 card to access restricted areas on space stations and outposts. If you want to craft AtlasPass v3 to access even more areas, you need the previously mentioned Emeril, too.

You will also need Cadmium for several main missions in No Man's Sky , including The First Traveller mission and one step of The Atlas Path mission. The rest of the Cadmium you can refine into Chromatic Metal, which is widely used for research and building.

item.title: 8 Most Satisfying First-Person Shooters
item.description:
Summary

  • Good gunplay is crucial in FPS games, along with hit responses and feedback.
  • Neon White offers unique, fast-paced gameplay with expressive movement and responsive weapons.
  • ULTRAKILL features skill-based scoring, fluid animations, and satisfying gunplay with pixelated gore.

The first-person shooter is a broad and varied genre, not to mention saturated. From the fast and frenetic pace of old-school shooters such as DOOM , to the slower pace of Call of Duty , there's something for all kinds of FPS fans.

Of all the qualities, good gunplay is perhaps the most important when it comes to first-person shooters. This, too, plays a pivotal role in making an FPS satisfying . However, other elements can make an FPS more gratifying to play, such as finely tuned hit responses and smooth player feedback.

8 Neon White

A Unique, Fast-Paced Title That Twists FPS Conventions

Far from being a straight shooter, Neon White is a truly unique title that emphasizes speed and quick-thinking. In the game, players blast through a variety of short levels in which they're tasked with defeating every enemy and reaching the end as fast as they can.

What makes Neon White so satisfying is its expressive movement and responsive weapons (represented by simple cards), which also double as special traversal abilities when they're discarded. Many of these abilities are also satisfying to use thanks to responsive controls and lightning-fast animations.

7 Post Void

A Frenetic Action Roguelike With Expressive Movement

Fast-paced, frenetic, and borderline psychedelic, Post Void is an action Roguelike with a kinetic personality. In the game, players barrel through labyrinthine levels while battling against various enemies and their constantly draining health.

The ephemeral nature of the player's health also helps to encourage speed and maintains the game's pace. Players can also refill their health by killing enemies, discouraging them from simply running past every adversary. This elegant design is elevated by the game's expressive movement controls and satisfying headshots. As a result, blasting through the many close-quarters environments of Post Void is a frequently gratifying experience.

6 Maximum Action

A Responsive Action Sandbox With An Emphasis On Style

  • Platform(s): PC
  • Released: 2018
  • Developer(s): George Mandell
  • Genre: FPS

Though it features little in the way of challenge, Maximum Action excels with its action-sandbox gameplay, emphasizing style over mechanical depth. This is no surprise, given that Maximum Action takes heavy inspiration from the action cinema of the 80s and 90s.

The diverse arsenal of weaponry available includes a variety of firearms that are brought to life through snappy animations and punchy sound effects, resulting in satisfying gunplay. The fast pace, lack of stakes, and complete focus on action keep Maximum Action a tight and rewarding experience despite a lack of narrative and progression.

5 ULTRAKILL

Weighty Gunplay Is Elevated By Skill-Based Scoring

ULTRAKILL is a fast-paced and intuitive first-person shooter with a focus on creative weaponry and pixelated gore. What's unique and ultimately satisfying about ULTRAKILL is the game's distinctive blend of old-school shooters and character action games.

In ULTRAKILL , players are rewarded for their skill with a classic score-based grading system, drawing satisfaction from the most basic of actions. This is only furthered by fluid animations, snappy gunplay, and hit feedback that elicits buckets of pixelated blood.

4 Warhammer 40,000: Boltgun

Weighty Movement And Punchy Hit Feedback

Set in the rich, grim-dark world of Warhammer 40,000 and taking inspiration from both modern and retro boomer shooters, Boltgun is an excessively violent romp that puts players in the heavy shoes of an Ultramarine. This title makes every effort to make players feel like a Space Marine, emphasizing the weight of the suit with a heavy gait and stomping footsteps.

The movement alone is satisfying, but it's complemented by the addition of a classic Warhammer 40,000 chainsword and the ability to charge enemies. The chunky sound effects and impactful animations ensure that player feedback is both obvious and satisfying.

3 Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege

Slick, Smooth Gunplay With Weighty Animations

This competitive shooter features a heavy focus on tactics and teamwork, but gunplay remains a core part of its gameplay loop. The variety of weapons and attachments keeps Rainbow Six Siege a strategic experience, but each firearm is satisfying to use in its own way thanks to punchy sound effects and weighty animations.

Hit response and player feedback are also fast and smooth, allowing this title to feel tremendously responsive. As with many competitive shooters, Rainbow Six Siege has its fair share of problems, but the satisfying gunplay makes up for most of it.

2 DOOM (2016)

Exaggerated Gunplay And Expressive Combat Arenas

Reviving fast-paced combat and arena-shooter gameplay with its relentless attitude and unabashed focus on action, 2016's DOOM is a tremendously unhinged FPS. The exaggerated animations and the weight applied to each of them give each action an impactful response, resulting in thoroughly satisfying gunplay.

The hectic combat arenas that make up most of DOOM are the perfect playgrounds for its arsenal of punchy firearms, further elevated by expressive movement and violent glory kills. These arenas are broken up by short passages of lower intensity, giving players a welcome palette cleanse between bloodbaths.

1 CULTIC

Crunchy Retro Sound Design And Buckets Of Pixelated Gore

Taking equal inspiration from old-school shooters such as Blood and survival-horror games such as Resident Evil 4 , CULTIC is a unique blend of satisfying gunplay, creative weaponry, and dense atmosphere. The horror elements are light, but certainly present, giving CULTIC a distinctive flavor.

Excessive, pixelated gore and crunchy, retro-styled sound effects ensure that the moment-to-moment gameplay of CULTIC is weighty, bolstered by an arsenal of punchy weapons. All this results in truly heavy, impactful gameplay that's tremendously satisfying.

item.title: 6 Open-World Games With The Most Cities And Towns, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Horizon Forbidden West: 31 diverse towns offer unique cultures and quests.
  • Mount & Blade 2: Bannerlord: Realistic medieval life with 53 towns.
  • Assassin's Creed Odyssey: 49-85 settlements in Ancient Greece bustling with life and history.

Open-world games let players play the game in their own way. Without levels or barriers, they are free to explore anywhere their eyes can see. However, exploring a world dotted by traces of civilization and seeing life flourish in all kinds of interesting places offers a comforting contrast between excursions into the wilderness.

While sculpting mountains and painting down trees might be the stuff of science fiction, for now, it's relatively easier to do in a game engine than hand-placed villagers or cities with their own populations. However, a few studios have seen fit to populate their worlds with a staggering number of settlements in their open-world games.

6 Horizon Forbidden West - 31 towns

A Diverse Neo-Tribal Landscape

In Horizon: Forbidden West , 30 vibrant towns dot the landscape in the main game, each representing different tribal factions that grew out of a beautiful apocalypse. From the bustling industrial town of Chainscrape to the peaceful, nature-infused Plainsong, each town brings its own unique culture and character to the nature-reclaimed post-apocalyptic landscape.

These settlements aren't just nice to visit and look at, as they contain vendors and weapon merchants and are hotspots to pick up a quest of two. The 31st settlement, Fleet's End, was added in the "Burning Shores" DLC and is far out of the way and not technically in the Forbidden West area itself but is found in the confines of the same game.

5 Mount & Blade 2: Bannerlord - 53 towns

A Vast Playground For The Mounted And Bladed

The fantasy of being able to pick up an edged weapon and jump on a stead to conquer the landscape wouldn't quite be the same without places to house peasants and admiring onlookers, each with their own fealties and cultures. Mount & Blade II: Bannerlord takes a fairly realistic approach to medieval life, with 53 towns and hundreds of villages across its expansive map.

These settlements are central to the game's combat, diplomacy, and economic systems and have plenty of interactivity and utility throughout the game. Conversely, if the player feels like it, they can even give up their life of amassing power and arms and live out their lives as beggars or traveling merchants among the people.

4 Assassin's Creed Odyssey - 49-85

The Ancient Living World Revived on a Massive Scale

Assassin's Creed Odyssey boasts a massive number of settlements, with 49 major cities and an additional 36 smaller towns scattered across its sprawling recreation of Ancient Greece. These settlements range from the iconic, bustling streets of Athens to the militarized simplicity of Sparta, with countless coastal ports and villages in between, a delight for fans of Ancient Greek history and mythology.

These locations aren't mere background decorations. They're alive with marketplaces, arenas, temples, and bustling NPCs going about their lives, even if most of them are non-interactable and the simulation is played out through ambient animations.

3 The Elder Scrolls 2: Daggerfall - At Least 5,040

An Entire Landmass Of Communities Spread Far And Wide

There are an astonishing 40 capital cities and somewhere around 5,000 smaller cities and towns to explore in Daggerfall , which means that sight-seeing completionists will have their work cut out for them. Daggerfall's map is roughly the size of real-life Great Britain, and each village feels about as far away from one another as they would be in real life.

Admittedly, given the limited amount of data storage available in the late 90s, there's only so much content to spread around this humongous, early, semi-procedurally generated map, and after the fourth or fifth, each town and village begins to feel a little samey. Fans of this concept may be excited to hear that the same developers behind the game are working on an equally ambitious spiritual sequel to Daggerfall , but this time with a little more content to spread around.

2 Minecraft - Potentially Infinite

A Near-Endless World Of Villages

So long as the "spawn structures" tickbox is checked during world generation, any given world in Minecraft can potentially have a near-infinite amount of villages to explore. The procedural generation sometimes leaves interesting results as roads and buildings clash with local geography, and given the endless possible combinations in the code, there's always a chance of finding something unique.

That also goes for villagers, too. While they may not have names (unless the player finds a way to name them using a nametag) or dialogue, villagers of each profession have items available to sell. These interactions (and the resulting product of each trade) make each village that much more memorable.

1 No Man's Sky - Potentially Infinite

A Near-Endless Galaxy Of Outposts

There isn't exactly a way to top an open world with literally a galaxy of planets and spaceworthy structures, each with a chance to harbor life and settlements, and that's exactly what happens in No Man's Sky , thanks to the mind-melting number of explorable planets in its universe, many containing one or more hubs of life. These hubs are a place to trade, find upgrades, and learn some alien lore.

Past a point, the variations in settlements do begin to break down under the stress of infinity, with many outposts and structures following familiar layouts and templates, but regardless, the sheer scale of No Man's Sky's universe makes running out of new towns to ride into literally impossible in a single human lifetime.

item.title: Infinity Nikki - Forced Perspective: Empty Flowerpot Guide
item.description:
Quick Links

  • How to Unlock Forced Perspective: Empty Flowerpot in Infinity Nikki
  • How to Complete Forced Perspective: Empty Flowerpot in Infinity Nikki

Some of the Forced Perspective quests in Infinity Nikki are much harder than they might initially appear. While the quest only requires you to snap one picture, finding the correct items and position is what makes them so difficult. For the Forced Perspective: Empty Flowerpot quest , you must find the correct flowerpot, and fill it in with some flowers and plants.

Completing this quest might seem daunting at first, especially if you can't seem to find the correct flowerpot and how to correctly stand in the right position to fill it in. If you are wondering how to complete Forced Perspective: Empty Flowerpot in Infinity Nikki , here's what you can do.

How to Unlock Forced Perspective: Empty Flowerpot in Infinity Nikki

Since Forced Perspective: Empty Flowerpot is relatively deep into Infinity Nikki , you will need to meet a few prerequisites first to have it unlocked. This includes:

  • Reach Chapter 6 and unlock the Wishing Woods.
  • Complete previous Forced Perspective quests (Caged Bird, Capturing the Thief, Ship in a Bottle, Flowers in Three Vases, Long-Eared Bunny).

As long as you follow the main story as it is given to you, and complete each Forced Perspective quest along the way, you will eventually have Forced Perspective: Empty Flowerpot unlocked for you. It will be located in the Wishing Woods during Chapter 6.

How to Complete Forced Perspective: Empty Flowerpot in Infinity Nikki

To find Forced Perspective: Empty Flowerpot in Infinity Nikki , you'll want to head to the Wishing Woods after you reach the Chapter 6 quest "Where is Afubo?" Then, make your way to the Wishcraft Lab Warp Spire , and head northeast to the spot shown on the map image above with the blue marker. In this area, you'll find Sopuda, and you'll want to talk to her to get the quest started.

  • Sopuda will ask for a picture of an empty flowerpot filled with flowers.
  • As you will see directly in front of Sopuda, close to the ground, there's an empty flowerpot.
  • To the left of the flowerpot, there are some yellow flowers growing in a patch on the ground.
  • Stand in front of the flowers as shown in the third image above, and then make sure to back up a little.
  • Now, open up the camera, and align the flowers so they look like they're planted in the flowerpot as shown in the fourth image.
  • After you've snapped the picture, return to Sopuda and show her the image you took in your Photobook.
  • After the quest is wrapped up, you'll receive 10x Diamonds, and 3x Upgrade Packs.

That's all there is to know about completing the Forced Perspective: Empty Flowerpot quest.
